summary: This document consists of two letters from U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta to Jeffrey Epstein's attorneys regarding the implementation of the Non-Prosecution Agreement. The first letter confirms the selection of an attorney representative for victims and addresses procedural matters. The second letter is a draft amended victim notification letter detailing the terms of Epstein's plea agreement and the rights of victims under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges of felony solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution in Palm Beach County and was sentenced to 12 months' imprisonment followed by 6 months' imprisonment and 12 months of community control.

events.title: Robert Josefsberg's Preparation as Attorney Representative
events.description: Robert Josefsberg expended time, effort, and funds in preparing to serve as the attorney representative for victims, as selected by the Special Master.

events.title: Initial Victim Notification Letter
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent an initial notification letter to victims, which contained information later deemed inaccurate and necessitated an amended notification.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office provided Epstein's counsel with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment, and stated none of those names would be deleted.
Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement required him to pay the fees and costs of the attorney representative (Robert Josefsberg) for victims in civil litigation, unless the litigation became contested.
Epstein waived his right to contest liability and damages up to an agreed amount in any suit filed under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255, though this was not construed as an admission of liability.
The U.S. Attorney's Office had previously provided victims with incorrect information in notification letters, which was approved by Epstein's counsel, and now needed to correct the error promptly.
Victims (or their attorneys) could obtain a copy of the actual agreement between Epstein and the United States if they signed a Protective Order.
